Literature Review: Xenolithic eclogites are fragments of ca. 3.0â€“1.8 Ga oceanic crust that have been extensively studied for their petrogenetic and geodynamic significance. These rocks are characterized by their eclogitic facies, which indicates that they have undergone high-pressure and high-temperature metamorphism. The presence of xenolithic eclogites in or near cratons has long been recognized as a remnant of Precambrian subducted oceanic crust that has undergone partial melting to yield granitoids similar to the Archean continental crust (Taylor & McLennan, 1985). The majority of xenolithic eclogites were deeply subducted to form lithologic and geochemical heterogeneities in the convecting mantle (Hoffmann et al., 2013). However, some eclogitized oceanic crust was emplaced into cratonic lithospheres, where it was variably modified subsequent to emplacement in Mesoarchean to Paleoproterozoic time (Bickle & Groves, 1991). The geodynamic significance of xenolithic eclogites encompasses four tectonic environments: (a) spreading ridges, where precursors formed by partial melting of convecting mantle and subsequent melt differentiation; (b) subduction zones, where oceanic crust was metamorphosed and interacted with other slab lithologies; (c) the cratonic mantle lithosphere, where the eclogite source was variably modified subsequent to emplacement; and (d) the convecting mantle, into which the vast majority of subduction-modified oceanic crust not captured in the cratonic lithosphere was recycled (Hoffmann et al., 2013). The origin of xenolithic eclogites is variably differentiated oceanic crust, followed by subduction metamorphism, and prolonged mantle residence (Taylor & McLennan, 1985). This process allows for the investigation of deep geochemical cycles related to recycling of Precambrian oceanic crust (Hoffmann et al., 2013). Xenolithic eclogites also help constrain asthenosphere thermal plus redox evolution and contribute to cratonic physical properties and mineral endowments (Bickle & Groves, 1991). The presence of xenolithic eclogites in cratons provides valuable insights into the evolution of the Earth's lithosphere and the processes that have shaped the planet's surface over billions of years. In this review, we will discuss the petrogenesis and geodynamic significance of xenolithic eclogites, with a focus on their role in the recycling of Precambrian oceanic crust and the evolution of the Earth's lithosphere.
